questions.text: When your phone charges wirelessly, what do you wonder about first?
I enjoy taking things apart to see how they work (and trying to reassemble them).
Given a messy dataset from a sensor, what’s your instinct?

options.label: Look for a quick visual trend and move on
Model sources of noise and test filters

questions.text: I build or fix things (electronics, bikes, PCs, 3D prints, small mechanisms).
Two materials are proposed for a new machine part. What do you do?

options.label: Choose what’s available and get started
Compare stress-strain data, cost, and environment of use
Derive the key equations behind a device
Build a prototype and test it

questions.text: I often ask ‘what if we tried it this other way?’ when solving problems.
A production line has a bottleneck. Your first move?

options.label: Map the process and collect timing data
Try a quick hardware tweak to see if it helps

questions.text: Translating theory into something that works in the real world is energizing.
Faced with a tricky measurement, you prefer to:

options.label: Calibrate and characterize the current setup first
Simulate heat flow and compare to experiment
Design a heat sink and machine it

questions.text: I like optimizing for cost, manufacturability, and safety — not just performance.
When a device fails intermittently, you:

options.label: Create a fault tree and isolate variables methodically

questions.text: I follow science/engineering channels, and I’m drawn to ‘how it works’ content.
I enjoy connecting physics principles to industries like energy, semiconductors, automation, or medical devices.

overall.strong: You strongly align with Industrial/Applied Physics. Your blend of {{TOP_TRAITS}} suggests you’ll enjoy design-build-test cycles and translating theory into practice.
overall.potential: You show signs of a good match. With exposure to labs or projects, your {{TOP_TRAITS}} can grow into a strong applied profile.
